Utilitarianism has been the subject of much debate in modern political theory since the publication of John Rawls’s massive and brilliant contractarian alternative, A Theory of Justice (Oxford, 1972). Utilitarianism is also inconsistent with the highly libertarian political theory of Robert Nozick in Anarchy, State and Utopia (Oxford, 1974). The tensions between Rawls, Nozick and utilitarianism are well brought out in Philip Pettit’s introduction to contemporary political theory, Judging Justice (London, 1980).
